summary: Email correspondence between attorneys regarding a draft protective order for the disclosure of a non-prosecution agreement to victims Jane Does 1 and 2 in the Epstein case. The emails discuss the terms and implementation of the protective order as directed by a judge.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Attorney representing Jane Does 1 and 2, proposing revisions to a draft protective order regarding disclosure of the non-prosecution agreement.

persons.name: Paul Cassell
persons.context: Copied on email discussing the draft protective order, likely involved in the legal representation of victims.

connections.description: Both are attorneys copied on correspondence regarding the protective order for victims, indicating they are working together on the case.

events.title: Judge's order on protective order
events.description: A judge issued an order regarding the implementation of a protective order for the disclosure of the non-prosecution agreement to victims.

keyFacts: A draft protective order is being negotiated for the disclosure of a non-prosecution agreement to victims Jane Does 1 and 2.
Attorney Brad Edwards argues that requiring victims to formally 'acknowledge receipt of the order and agree to its terms' could cause unnecessary delay.
The correspondence indicates ongoing legal proceedings and protective measures around the Epstein non-prosecution agreement in August 2008.
